intro: Vincetoxicum helferi, commonly known as the red elderberry, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern North America. It belongs to the family Adoxaceae and is characterized by its clusters of small, showy red berries that appear in late summer. The plant produces compound leaves with serrated edges and can grow up to 6 feet tall. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and is often found in moist, well-drained soils. The berries are toxic to humans and animals but are a food source for certain birds and wildlife.
